pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw: How does this handle the case of overlapping virtual evidence regions? I believe this has been discussed numerous times between @{557058:e439e22e-8cfc-4cf1-b090-030d33a0730e} and @{557058:a9657985-692c-405c-995b-4e41cda7ba2b} . From the description it’s not clear what should happen if two regions only partially overlap. Unfortunately I have not kept any notes on the discussion pertaining to this PR. Currently in this PR it looks like there’s only an error thrown for overlapping regions with the same label.
content.html: How does this handle the case of overlapping virtual evidence regions? I believe this has been discussed numerous times between @Rachel Chan and @Michael Hoffman . From the description it’s not clear what should happen if two regions only partially overlap. Unfortunately I have not kept any notes on the discussion pertaining to this PR. Currently in this PR it looks like there’s only an error thrown for overlapping regions with the same label.

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw:
I’m not sure what you mean by overlapping. Each label should be defined on its own line, so label definitions will have to overlap. Two of the same labels may not overlap however, though it was discussed trying to average them.

For example this is a valid VE file for our purposes:

```
chr1 0 10 1 0.7
chr1 0 5 0 0.3
chr1 6 10 0 0.2
```

Even though line one overlaps with lines 2 and 3 it applies to a different label.

This VE file would cause an error since label 0 would overlap with itself.

```
chr1 0 10 0 0.6
chr1 5 20 0 0.4
```

‌
content.html:
I’m not sure what you mean by overlapping. Each label should be defined on its own line, so label definitions will have to overlap. Two of the same labels may not overlap however, though it was discussed trying to average them.

For example this is a valid VE file for our purposes:

chr1 0 10 1 0.7
chr1 0 5 0 0.3
chr1 6 10 0 0.2

Even though line one overlaps with lines 2 and 3 it applies to a different label.

This VE file would cause an error since label 0 would overlap with itself.

chr1 0 10 0 0.6
chr1 5 20 0 0.4

‌

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw:
OK. There are some things here that are not clear from the description in terms of desired behaviour in this case:

1. What happens when the probabilities of overlapping labels is >1 \(as shown\)?
2. Are the non-overlapping regions above have their remaining probability uniformly distributed?
3. How does remaining probability get distributed say when two labels overlap with a probability >1 and the remaining label does not have have any probability defined for it \(chr1 75 150 region above\)?

‌
content.html:
OK. There are some things here that are not clear from the description in terms of desired behaviour in this case:

  1. What happens when the probabilities of overlapping labels is >1 (as shown)?
  2. Are the non-overlapping regions above have their remaining probability uniformly distributed?
  3. How does remaining probability get distributed say when two labels overlap with a probability >1 and the remaining label does not have have any probability defined for it (chr1 75 150 region above)?

‌

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw: Sorry I didn’t notice the probabilities. Yes it will raise an error saying that VE probabilities must sum to <=1 at all positions. A small allowance \(0.001\) was put in for EGPR which can sometimes produce labels just above 1 due to rounding.
content.html: Sorry I didn’t notice the probabilities. Yes it will raise an error saying that VE probabilities must sum to <=1 at all positions. A small allowance (0.001) was put in for EGPR which can sometimes produce labels just above 1 due to rounding.

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw:
I have some general comments on this function as a whole:

1. `prior_list` should be completely clear on it’s type. In the description it looks like the downsampling returns a dictionary? Is the input a dictionary or a list of lists? Must there be a value for every label at this point?
2. The input of `prior_list` is not clear on what/if there exists a probability defined for every label before “downsampling”. Not until farther down the function do you realize this is not the case and hence the need for the uniform fill on remaining probabilites/etc. It might be considered a separate transformation/function.
3. `num_segs` although following some psuedo-convention in this module is a misnomer. It has nothing to do with the number of segments, which is confusing in a downsampling context. It is the number of labels \(unless I’m mistaken\). `num_labels` seems more appropriate.
4. It looks like there’s virtually nothing shared calculation-wise between downsampling the presence and list of prior dictionaries. It looks like the two portions should split apart. If there’s shared patterns of code between them, then those should be split into functions themselves \(say perhaps the resolution partitioning portion of the code\).

‌
content.html:
I have some general comments on this function as a whole:

  1. prior_list should be completely clear on it’s type. In the description it looks like the downsampling returns a dictionary? Is the input a dictionary or a list of lists? Must there be a value for every label at this point?
  2. The input of prior_list is not clear on what/if there exists a probability defined for every label before “downsampling”. Not until farther down the function do you realize this is not the case and hence the need for the uniform fill on remaining probabilites/etc. It might be considered a separate transformation/function.
  3. num_segs although following some psuedo-convention in this module is a misnomer. It has nothing to do with the number of segments, which is confusing in a downsampling context. It is the number of labels (unless I’m mistaken). num_labels seems more appropriate.
  4. It looks like there’s virtually nothing shared calculation-wise between downsampling the presence and list of prior dictionaries. It looks like the two portions should split apart. If there’s shared patterns of code between them, then those should be split into functions themselves (say perhaps the resolution partitioning portion of the code).

‌

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw:
1. prior\_list is a numpy array of priors for every position that the user defined. If the user did not define any priors at that coordinate, it will contain an array of 0. The output of this function is a list of lists containing the downsampled priors. The dictionary was used for clarity in the docstring and this notation will be changed to reflect the actual output. All this will be added to the docstring to make the function more clear.

‌
content.html:
1. prior_list is a numpy array of priors for every position that the user defined. If the user did not define any priors at that coordinate, it will contain an array of 0. The output of this function is a list of lists containing the downsampled priors. The dictionary was used for clarity in the docstring and this notation will be changed to reflect the actual output. All this will be added to the docstring to make the function more clear.

‌

3. num_segs will be changed here as well as in task.py to num_labels for clarity; though this does differ from notation used in run.py

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw: `any` is being applied to a boolean expression which will _always_ return `True` I believe. Get rid of the `!= None`. I’m not sure what the point of it is. I’m not sure if it’s necessary to even put it outside the `any` call like `any(prior_list)  != None` .
content.html: any is being applied to a boolean expression which will always return True I believe. Get rid of the != None. I’m not sure what the point of it is. I’m not sure if it’s necessary to even put it outside the any call like any(prior_list) != None .

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw:
prior\_list is actually a one-dimensional numpy array. So, this expression will return a boolean array. The reason the != None exists is to account for someone who only specifies a single label as 0 probability. This could result in an array looking something like:

`[0, None, None]`

If this were passed to any\(prior\_list\) it would return False, but needs to be true so we can apply the proper prior to the other two labels.
content.html:
prior_list is actually a one-dimensional numpy array. So, this expression will return a boolean array. The reason the != None exists is to account for someone who only specifies a single label as 0 probability. This could result in an array looking something like:

[0, None, None]

If this were passed to any(prior_list) it would return False, but needs to be true so we can apply the proper prior to the other two labels.

If you’re breaking down some of these functions further it would be prime candidates for this type of testing and increasing our confidence that the code is behaving as expected.

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw:
I am concerned about this approach--I assume that either things will add up to `1.0` exactly or that comparing with a slop of machine epsilon will not be enough given the number of operations that could have gone into these numbers. We could take two approaches here:

1. we could just trust that the input at this stage is correct and let GMTK deal with any deviations from adding up to 1.0. I assume that it already does this just fine. We should check user input closer to the user but not here. I think I would favor this, if that’s the case; or
2. we could rescale `mean_prior_vector`, multiplying each cell by the inverse of `sum(mean_prior_vector)`. That would ensure it adds up to `1.0` as best we can manage.

‌
content.html:
I am concerned about this approach--I assume that either things will add up to 1.0 exactly or that comparing with a slop of machine epsilon will not be enough given the number of operations that could have gone into these numbers. We could take two approaches here:

  1. we could just trust that the input at this stage is correct and let GMTK deal with any deviations from adding up to 1.0. I assume that it already does this just fine. We should check user input closer to the user but not here. I think I would favor this, if that’s the case; or
  2. we could rescale mean_prior_vector, multiplying each cell by the inverse of sum(mean_prior_vector). That would ensure it adds up to 1.0 as best we can manage.

‌

content.html: This is essentially obsolete at this point, since priors summing above 1 would have already been discovered in get_downsampled_virtual_evidence_data_and_priors. I would suggest this check be removed and use the one in the other function exclusively, if a hard cap or continuing to be epsilon.

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw: In this case a vector of \[0.0, 0.0, 0.0\] is used almost as a standin for a row of NA in our calculations. These are rows where no priors have been specified and so are ignored in the mean calculation. Ignoring them here is made up for by having the presence be 2 at this index
content.html: In this case a vector of [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] is used almost as a standin for a row of NA in our calculations. These are rows where no priors have been specified and so are ignored in the mean calculation. Ignoring them here is made up for by having the presence be 2 at this index

content.html: Should not use an epsilon comparison here--should be exactly 0.0 unless something has been set.

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw:
Should use `array.sum()` not `sum(array).`

Also should use `numpy.absolute()` not `__builtins__.abs()`. Use numpy functions not `math` or builtin functions whenever possible
content.html:
Should use array.sum() not sum(array).

Also should use numpy.absolute() not __builtins__.abs(). Use numpy functions not math or builtin functions whenever possible

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw:
Machine epsilon isn’t going to be enough slop to keep from producing errors from inputs that a user would think are good.

```
>>> abs(sum(array([0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1], dtype=float32)) - 1) < EPSILON
False
```

‌
content.html:
Machine epsilon isn’t going to be enough slop to keep from producing errors from inputs that a user would think are good.

>>> abs(sum(array([0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1], dtype=float32)) - 1) < EPSILON
False

‌

content.raw:
You should do all this with numpy operations.

Build an array that has 1 where you have None in the original. sum that to get the divisor. Then use it as a mask to set those positions to what you now call the uniform prior.
content.html:
You should do all this with numpy operations.

Build an array that has 1 where you have None in the original. sum that to get the divisor. Then use it as a mask to set those positions to what you now call the uniform prior.

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw:
This may have got lost in an e-mail discussion, however as per requested by @{557058:a9657985-692c-405c-995b-4e41cda7ba2b} \(his words below\):

```
break out the current EPSILON checks to use a new check_is_close() function that
1.checks whether things sum exactly to 1.0 or 0.0 or whatever is wanted

2. use warning.warn() with a custom warn class if there is any deviation (and specify the amount of the deviation)
```

The warning class has been addressed - just the function would need to be added
content.html:
This may have got lost in an e-mail discussion, however as per requested by @Michael Hoffman (his words below):

break out the current EPSILON checks to use a new check_is_close() function that
1.checks whether things sum exactly to 1.0 or 0.0 or whatever is wanted

2. use warning.warn() with a custom warn class if there is any deviation (and specify the amount of the deviation)

The warning class has been addressed - just the function would need to be added
